sentences: The sheriff said that he did not yet know who the captor or captors were, what the motive was or where Papini had been held these three weeks. He released few details, explaining it is an ongoing police investigation, and he asked the media to respect the family's privacy at this time.

Investigators have spoken with Papini but hoped to get more information soon in the effort to uncover what had happened over the last three weeks, Bosenko said. They did not have information on where she was kept or if the abduction was planned or impulsive.

Papini was found in Yolo County, California, about 140 miles from the Mountain Gate trail where she was last seen.

A woman who was kidnapped and held captive for three weeks after leaving her northern California home to jog was found safe on the side of a rural road bound in restraints, a local sheriff said Friday.
A    mother of two who was found in restraints near a highway in California on Thanksgiving Day after disappearing on Nov. 2 was "emotional" but elated to be free, the local sheriff said.
Highway patrol officers put Sherri Papini on the phone with her husband minutes after she was discovered bound near Interstate 5 in Yolo County, Calif. since going missing three weeks ago.
On Thursday, Sherri Papini told authorities that she had been taken by two Latino women armed with a handgun, and who drove a   SUV, Sheriff Tom Bosenko said.
Authorities were looking for two armed women they believe abducted Sherri Papini, 34, on 2 November, Shasta County sheriff Tom Bosenko said in an interview on Good Morning America.

"We are ecstatic to report that Sherri Papini has been located and has been reunited with her family on this day of Thanksgiving," Shasta County Sheriff Tom Bosenko told reporters Thursday during a news conference.
Papini had suffered injuries, Bosenko said, though he would not say what the injuries were or exactly how she was restrained; she was taken to an undisclosed hospital for treatment, he said.

Papini was treated at a   hospital for unspecified injuries and released. Officials said they were not aware of a motive for the kidnapping and did not know if Papini knew the women who kidnapped her.
After authorities arrived, she was taken to a hospital for treatment and released.

"The investigation is far from over. '' Papini, a    mother of two, disappeared on Nov. 2 after she left her Redding home to go on a jog. Her husband, Keith, reported her missing when she failed to pick up their kids, ages 2 and 4, from day care. Investigators later found her cellphone, earbuds and a few strands of her hair along a rural road.

The sheriff said Papini, from the Redding area, had gone for a   jog Nov. 2 while her husband, Keith, was at work; when she did not pick up her children from day care or return home that evening, her husband started to worry.

Many questions still, On Thanksgiving Day, Sherri's husband Keith    who had made a teary public appeal for her return    was at at his wife's side. But questions remain about what happened to the    mother of two since her disappearance on November 2. Did she know her  abductors?
Papini disappeared after going for a jog near her home in Redding, more than 100 miles north of the roadside where she was found Thursday.
Where was she held?
She was found about 150 miles south of where she disappeared in Redding.

According to the GoFundMe page: Keith reported to deputies that upon his arrival home from work, he was not able to locate Sherri or their two children. Keith learned that the children had not been picked up from day care as customary and subsequently checked his find my   app and located Sherri's phone near the intersection of Old Oregon Trail and Sunrise Drive in Redding.

Her husband discovered she had gone missing when she didn't pick up their two children from daycare. Using the Find My iPhone app, he found her cell phone and ear buds about a mile from their home. Strands of hair were on the earbuds, and authorities described her as an   missing person.
Her husband reported her missing when she failed to pick up their two young children from daycare, something her family members said was completely out of character, according to the Sacramento Bee.
30am on Thanksgiving morning near Interstate 5 and was able to flag down a driver, Bosenko said. The driver called authorities, who connected the mother of two to her husband by cellphone.
The Shasta County Sheriff's Office said Sherri Papini was able to flag down a driver outside the city of Yolo around 4:30 a. m. Thursday, bound with restraints and injured.
Bosenko said Papini "was released by her captor on a rural road near  .
"She was bound with restraints but was able to summon help by a passing motorist who then notified law enforcement,'' Bosenko said.

Police said Sherri Papini, 34, who was bound in restraints, flagged down a passing motorist, who immediately alerted law enforcement.
Bosenko said Papini had been released by her captors, but it was not known why. He asked for anyone with information to contact police so those involved could be brought to justice.

"Obviously she was emotional and quite upset but elated to be freed, and so we were able to get some information from her. Then in the days following this, we will be following up with her,'' he said.

"Obviously she was emotional and quite upset, but elated to be freed, and so we were able to get some information from her," Bosenko said. "Then, in the days following this, we will be following up with her. " Family members previously called her a "super mom" who would never abandon her family.

Bosenko did not elaborate on the women's relationship to the case. "Even though Sherri has been located and reunited with her family, this investigation is far from over; this has only begun a new chapter in the investigation," Bosenko said. He met her at the hospital, where he has been "at his wife's side," Bosenko said. When asked by reporters how Papini is doing, Bosenko said, "Obviously she is very relieved to be returned home safely and be reunited with her husband. "
"She was very emotional to be released and hear her husband's voice and then a few hours later to be reunited with him," the sheriff said.
